title: Science: What podcasts and radio shows are similar to 'Radiolab'? - Quora
tags: If I like X, will I like Y?

response.answer_text: So, full disclosure, I'm an NPR editor, so apologies for (belatedly) answering an NPR-related question with links to more NPR stuff, plus one from our colleagues at PRI. While not necessarily "sciencey" -- to use a Robert Krulwich term -- you'll hear some of that RadioLab/This American Life sound, style and production values in a few other public media podcasts: State of the Re:Union (Al Lenton's audio tour of the country): http://n.pr/yDXZYJ NPR's Planet Money podcasts: http://n.pr/zN2EMS I'm also a fan of Studio 360, which originates from RadioLab's home at WNYC and is distributed by PRI: http://www.studio360.org/ (Podcast: http://www.studio360.org/audio/podcasts/) Cultural, not science, but with a good dose of technology and imagination. For interviews, NPR's Science Friday podcast is here: http://www.npr.org/rss/podcast/podcast_detail.php?siteId=13994790 And for your reading pleasure, RadioLab's Robert Krulwich is also blogging here on "Krulwich Wonders": http://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/ And there's NPR "culture and cosmos" commentary blog, "13.7" (that's the age of the universe, in case you're wondering). It's written by a great group of scientists: http://www.npr.org/blogs/13.7/

Radiolab is ultimately about pinpointing curious ideas from around the globe, merging together the worlds of scientific thought and human experience cohesively, and illustrating how those ideas shape individual lives and society as a whole. I would submit to Quora readers that Data Crunch does the same thing, but from the specific angle of how the seemingly abstract and tech-heavy ideas of data, analytics, and algorithms blend into our everyday human journey. The episodes wrap these hidden yet ubiquitous concepts into compelling societal narratives. http://vaultanalytics.com/datacrunch/
